narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: After taking this class, I have decided which area I would like to work in. This class was my life-changing class.

Even before his injury, it was hard to feel like Professor Mendelsohn cared a flying hoot about this class. I'm pretty sure he glanced at the syllabus on his walk over to Sage. Remember when you were in undergrad and you felt like the Professors felt like teaching you was charity work? It was a bit like that.On the other hand, Professor M is a brilliant economist, and when he shows up, has some interesting insights.Overall though, I think I would have been better off skipping class and going to discussion session taught by the TA.

I appreciated Professor Mendelsohn's lecturing style. He shows a great depth of knowledge and has an engaging style. My one critique of his style is that he often cuts off students mid-question before they get to complete their thought.This was one of my favorite courses this semester.

Readings were all old. Some classes didn't feel like they had a clear point and were disorganized. Notes on the board, slides in advance, or any kind of organization would have been more helpful. Sometimes answers to student questions were distractions. More guidance needed on how to actually do the "data magic", since "how to analyze this data" was tested on the midterm and final but wasn't fully discussed in class. Laura was great. Final was boring to take and didn't test the full range of what we had learned by studying on our own.

I think the material of this course was comprehensive and relevant to the interests of FES students. The discussions were always enjoyable and clear and I appreciated the inclusion of econometric formulas and methods for analyzing the data of each valuation method.

Although the course began strongly and we actually discussed the content of the assigned reading, the later we got into the semester, the less care was paid to the details of the actual economics. There was a strong disconnect between the attention to detail and the academic rigor of the reading material and the content of the lecture.

This class is very important if people from a science background wish to expand their knowledge on valuation concepts, techniques, and how to develop robust explantations for economic, policy decision-making.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Structure of the lecture was very good and helpful.Professor Mendelsohn clearly explained the main concepts and gave supporting examples
Prof. Mendelsohn and his thoughts on environmental issues are the BEST parts of this course. If nothing else, you are made smarter with your view of the world through his eyes.
Professor gives really clear explanations about hard topics that would have been really hard to understand without his help.
Prof M's hilarious comments - such as referring to the panel data technique as the "great white hype," or that as environmental managers we will be the "fashion stars of tomorrow."
Expertise of the professor. Readings were great too.
The readings and the lecture topics were well related and relevant to my program.
Learning about the strengths and weaknesses of the techniques and their evolution over time. Laura's review sessions were very helpful.
The depth of detail given to each method was incredibly helpful and insightful.
A well-structured and sound introduction to the literature on non-market valuation.

- The instructor: professor Mendelsohn is extremely responsive and makes his classes an interesting discussion. His knowledge and confidence in teaching are the main aspects that make his course really good.- The pace: the rhythm is set by students and their interests. The instructor does not try to impose knowledge, but is open to adapt the pace to students' interests.- The readings offering both sides of an issue: we are provided with different opinions on the valuations issues - this is really useful!
The content, the readings, and the discussions sessions.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Needs a clearer understanding of exam related questions
I just wish Prof. M would be present in the room. I'm paying a lot for this degree and I'd like my professors to care a little bit more.I would also appreciate more organized lectures.
More organized classes would be better. More student participation would also be good.
What was expected of students was a bit unclear. We did not get much guidance on the paper we were to write other than a few reminders that it was coming.
Organization. Structure/make-up of midterm and final. Opportunities to practice throughout the term. Guidance on final paper.
This course needs to be more explicit about whether it is a discussion course about economics or a methods course that actually digs into the 'science' of economics.
Readings could be more updated (or at least we could be offered with old and recent papers).
More practical and mathematical concepts through problem sets

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Discussion sessions given by TA was really informative!
I only went to the discussion session once, and Laura explained it way more clearly than Prof. M did.
The sessions were a great review.
It was very effective because ti have a baseline from where to study.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Very convincing teaching skills, broad and deep knowledge of the topics, always available and helpful
She is just excelent!!
Strengths: responsive, respectful and very exciting about teachingWeakness: sometimes answers were to open and could be a bit more clarifying once the TA gets more teaching experience.
Instructor: Laura Ann Bakkensen  She has been great and helpful every step of the way for me.
Instructor: Laura Ann Bakkensen  She was great. Super accessible and always ready to help.

Instructor: Laura Ann Bakkensen  Very organized, explained concepts in easy-to-understand, structured manner, and relationships between different models.Would have been helpful to have one final review just quickly going over pros/cons of each model we learned as a refresher.

Instructor: Laura Ann Bakkensen  Laura had to give the lecture one day while the professor was out. It was a well-conceived and well-presented lecture. One of the best of the semester actually! Great job Laura!
Instructor: Laura Ann Bakkensen  Laura was great during review sessions, clearly and helpfully laying out concepts and asking questions.
Instructor: Laura Ann Bakkensen  Laura was responsive, communicative and supportive.
Instructor: Laura Ann Bakkensen  Strengths: very patient, very knowledgable on different techniques, and great TA

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Elective lecture that I chose out of personal interest
Economics is one of the areas that can be neglected by scientists. I am so glad that I could take this class this semester so that I can make new approaches when I see new environmental issues.
I like economics and policy. I want to understand econ papers.
We do not put a price to the environment but we need to value it. Therefore, environmental valuation is a core ingredient to environmental policy paradigms.

I have taken several real estate courses at SOM based on traditional land acquistion and real estate valuations premised on discounted cash flows of future revenue streams. Good to combine that with these economic models for trying to calculate a value for social, environmental, and other intrinsic values of a site.

I was able to use this course towards the development of my summer research methodology, which was very helpful. The term paper served as an initial research overview/proposal for this summer work, which was something I needed to write regardless.
A strong foundation in economics is a prerequisite for resource management.
This course was a must for me, as my training focus is valuation/economics of tropical forests.
This course is very well structured and fits perfectly as a class that gives one a background on how better decision-making can be done through different economic tools.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: recommendation from other classmates.
Because I have never been exposed to the topic of environmental valuation, and I was curious to learn more.
I liked what it had to offer

See comment above:I have taken several real estate courses at SOM based on traditional land acquistion and real estate valuations premised on discounted cash flows of future revenue streams. Good to combine that with these economic models for trying to calculate a value for social, environmental, and other intrinsic values of a site.Professor is very engaging and excellent at explaining complicated models in a manner that is conceptually accessible and rooted in real-life examples that I could relate to.
Thought I would learn the process/method for carrying out these techniques.
See Question 17.
Because I was interested on reviewing natural resource valuation tools for natural capital.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes.
It was much better than myexpectation. I think that this is class if one of the best classes that I have taken at F&ES.
yes
Sort of? I mean, I don't feel like I did anything for this course, except our final paper.
Yes, it exceeded my expectations.
Yes, it very much did
Yes
I actually was expecting more of an ecosystem services valuation focus to the course. But material that I learned was just as useful to me.
Not really.
Yes it did. I would still like to learn a bit more about how to analyze data in Stata but I feel that this is a skill I will learn through applied practice.
No - I expected a stronger, more rigorous discussion of the economic method.
Yes! I learned about the main valuation techniques, applications and main studies in the area.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Try to understand the concepts of different methods and how to apply them to the real world.
To take it.
If you want an easy course, take it. If you want substantive stuff, look elsewhere.

If you are looking for something to help you with environmental policy and economics...you should take it...I believe everybody should take it to understand how environmental decision making happens. The course is not restricted to economics focused students.
Great professor! Great introduction to quantitative methods for valuing a site aside from its revenue streams!
Do the reading, it really makes lecture more interesting.
Keep an open mind about economic valuation and be willing to learn from the professor, while also challenging some of the statements to foster interesting class dialogue.
This course is a philosophical discussion course, not an economic methods course.

Be patient at the beginning and do your readings. If you don't do your readings, you can follow the class but they won't be as interesting as they could be. And more importantly, remembering you are taking the class with one of the most admirable and renowned scientist in the area of valuation (among others)! Take advantage of this and enjoy the discussions in class.
Do all the readings and have a take it on your second semester!
